note_text:
INDICATIONS: Completed stent trial
Consent was obtained from the patient prior to procedure after explanation in lay terms the indications, details of procedure, and potential risks and alternatives. 
Sedation: General Anesthesia
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The procedure was performed in the bronchoscopy suite. Once the patient was sedated and paralyzed a 13 mm non-ventilating rigid tracheoscope was inserted through the mouth into the sublottic glottic space. A flexible T190 Olympus bronchoscope was inserted through the tracheoscope into the trachea and airway inspection was performed. The patient’s uncovered Ultraflex SEM stents in the trachea and bilateral main stems were widely patent with minimal intraluminal mucous. The flexible bronchoscope was removed and the rigid optic was reinserted alongside rigid alligator forceps. The forceps were used to grasp the proximal limb of the tracheal stent and were rotated repeatedly while withdrawing the stent into the rigid bronchoscope.  The stent was subsequently removed without difficulty.  Once his stent was removed the 12mm ventilating rigid bronchoscope was inserted through the tracheoscope and advanced to the distal trachea at which point the left and right main stem stents were also removed in a similar fashion, flexible bronchoscope was reinserted for repeat airway inspection.  There was moderate inflammation with slight granulation issue in the mucosa surrounding the previous stents with slow oozing of blood most predominantly in the distal trachea and main stem bronchi. There was also marked residual malacia which required conversion from open jet ventilation to closed conventional ventilation to main stem airway patency. The areas of active oozing were then treated with APC painting of the mucosa until sufficient hemostasis was achieved. At this point the rigid bronchoscope was removed and the procedure was completed. 

Recommendations:
Transfer to PACU
Discharge patient once criteria is met
Follow-up with CT surg regarding planned surgical tracheoplasty

diagnostic_bronchoscopy.inspection_findings: Stents widely patent with minimal mucous. Moderate inflammation and granulation tissue surrounding stents. Slow oozing post-removal. Marked residual malacia.

cao_interventions_detail.notes: Post-stent removal granulation and oozing; marked residual malacia.
Post-stent removal granulation and oozing; marked residual malacia.
Post-stent removal granulation and oozing; marked residual malacia.

complications.other_complication_details: Slow oozing of blood requiring APC for hemostasis; marked residual malacia requiring conversion to closed ventilation.

outcomes.follow_up_plan_text: Follow-up with CT surgery regarding planned surgical tracheoplasty.

cpt_codes.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible; with removal of foreign body

lines.description: Bronchoscopy; with removal of foreign body
lines.selection_reason: Removal of airway stents (trachea and mainstems).

per_code.summary: Removal of stents (foreign bodies) supports 31635. APC used for hemostasis is integral.

note_text:
Indications: Diagnosis and staging of presumed lung cancer
Medications: General Anesthesia
Procedure, risks, benefits, and alternatives were explained to the patient. All questions were answered and informed consent was documented as per institutional protocol. A history and physical were performed and updated in the pre-procedure assessment record. Laboratory studies and radiographs 
Following intravenous medications as per the record and topical anesthesia to the upper airway and tracheobronchial tree, the Q190 video bronchoscope was introduced through the ET tube into the tracheobronchial tree.   Tracheomalacia was noted in the trachea. The carina was sharp. The right-sided airway anatomy was normal. The left sided airway anatomy was normal. No evidence of endobronchial disease was seen to at least the first sub-segments. A systematic hilar and mediastinal lymph node survey was carried out. Sampling criteria (5mm short axis diameter) were met in station 11L  (5.4mm) and 4R (5.5mm) lymph nodes.  Sampling by transbronchial needle aspiration was performed beginning with the 11L Lymph node, followed by 4R lymph nodes using an Olympus Visioshot EBUSTBNA 22 gauge needle. ROSE showed non-diagnostic tissue in the low probability 11L lymph node and benign lymphocytes in the 4Rs. All samples were sent for routine cytology. The Q190 video bronchoscope was then re-inserted and after suctioning blood and secretions there was no evidence of active bleeding and the bronchoscope was subsequently removed.

Complications: No immediate complications
Estimated Blood Loss: 5 cc.

Post Procedure Diagnosis:
- Technically successful flexible bronchoscopy with endobronchial ultrasound-guided biopsies.
- The patient has remained stable and has been transferred in good condition to the post-surgical monitoring unit.
- Will await final pathology results

note_text:
Indications: Diagnosis and staging of presumed lung cancer
Medications: General Anesthesia
Topical: 80mg of lidocaine (8cc of 1%)
Consent was obtained from the patient prior to procedure after explanation in lay terms the indications, details of procedure, and potential risks and alternatives. All questions were answered and informed consent was documented as per institutional protocol. A history and physical were performed and updated in the pre-procedure assessment record. Laboratory studies and radiographs were reviewed. A time-out was performed prior to the intervention.
Following intravenous medications as per the record and topical anesthesia to the upper airway and tracheobronchial tree, the T190 video bronchoscope was introduced through the mouth, via laryngeal mask airway and advanced to the tracheobronchial tree. The laryngeal mask airway was in good position. The vocal cords were normal. The subglottic space was normal. The trachea was of normal caliber. The carina was sharp. The tracheobronchial tree was examined to at least the first subsegmental level. Left sided bronchial mucosa and anatomy were normal; without endobronchial lesions. The right mainstem, right upper lobe and proximal 80% of the bronchus intermedius was normal caliber without endobronchial lesions or mucosal irregularities. Mild extrinsic compression was present in the distal 20% of the bronchus intermedius. There was submucosal infiltration in the right middle lobe take off however it was widely patent. In the right lower lobe bronchus (just past the middle lobe take off) there was approximately 75% airway obstruction from a combination of submucosal infiltration and extrinsic tumor compression. The superior segment of the right lower lobe was 100% occluded. The bronchoscope was advanced past the obstruction which was about 1.5 cm in length and the basilar segments appeared uninvolved and were widely patent. 
The video bronchoscope was then removed and the UC180F convex probe EBUS bronchoscope was introduced through the mouth, via laryngeal mask airway and advanced to the tracheobronchial tree. A systematic hilar and mediastinal lymph node survey was carried out. Sampling criteria (5mm short axis diameter) were met in station 11L( 5.7mm), 7( 7.8mm) , !!rs (12.5 mm)  and 11Ri lymph nodes. The 11Ri lymph node was continuous with the primary tumor and involved by direct extension. The lymph node/mass was measured at 28.0 mm on ultrasonography. Sampling by transbronchial needle aspiration was performed with the Olympus EBUSTBNA 22 gauge needle beginning with the 11L Lymph node, followed by the 7 lymph node and finally the 11Ri/mass. The 11Rs was not sampled as this would not affect stage given the 11Ri involvement.  A total of 5 biopsies were performed in the 11L and 7 lymph node stations. Rapid on-site assessment of the station 11L was non-diagnostic (however low probability node so further sampling was not performed), and station 7 was normal lymphocytes. The 11Ri/mass was malignant favoring squamous cell carcinoma based on ROSE. A total of 9 needle passes were performed to ensure adequate material for PD L-1 and next generation sequencing with the majority of passes placed directly into cell block.  All samples were sent for routine cytology. Following completion of EBUS bronchoscopy, the Q190 video bronchoscope was then re-inserted and after suctioning blood and secretions there was no evidence of active bleeding and the bronchoscope was subsequently removed.
Complications: No immediate complications
Estimated Blood Loss: 10cc
Post Procedure: presumed lung cancer
Assessment/Plan: 
- Technically successful endobronchial ultrasound-guided mediastinal staging examination.
- The patient has remained stable and has been transferred in good condition to the post-procedural monitoring unit.

clinical_context.primary_indication: Diagnosis and staging of presumed lung cancer
clinical_context.radiographic_findings: Review of radiographs mentioned; findings not explicitly detailed in H&P section but implied by procedure (e.g., mass).
clinical_context.lesion_location: Right lower lobe bronchus / 11Ri lymph node mass

diagnostic_bronchoscopy.inspection_findings: Vocal cords normal. Trachea normal. RLL 75% airway obstruction from submucosal infiltration and extrinsic compression. Superior segment RLL 100% occluded.

outcomes.preliminary_diagnosis: Presumed squamous cell carcinoma of the lung (Right Lower Lobe) with N1 nodal involvement.

linear_ebus_stations_detail.notes: Low probability node, further sampling not performed.
Station 11Ri/mass. Malignant favoring squamous cell carcinoma. Continuous with primary tumor.
Station 11Rs. Not sampled as would not affect stage given 11Ri involvement.

note_text:
Indications: Diagnosis and staging of presumed lung cancer
Medications: General Anesthesia, 1% Lidocaine, tracheobronchial tree 14 mL. 
Procedure, risks, benefits, and alternatives were explained to the patient. All questions were answered and informed consent was documented as per institutional protocol. A history and physical were performed and updated in the preprocedure assessment record. Laboratory studies and radiographs were reviewed. A time-out was performed prior to the intervention.
 Following intravenous medications as per the record and topical anesthesia to the upper airway and tracheobronchial tree, the Q190 video bronchoscope was introduced through the mouth, via laryngeal mask airway and advanced to the tracheobronchial tree. The laryngeal mask airway was in good position. A brown plaque of unclear significance was seen on the epiglottis. The vocal cords appeared normal. The subglottic space was normal. The trachea was of normal caliber. The carina was sharp. The tracheobronchial tree was examined to at least the first subsegmental level. Bronchial mucosa and anatomy were normal; there are no endobronchial lesions, and no secretions. The video bronchoscope was then removed and the UC180F convex probe EBUS bronchoscope was introduced through the mouth, via laryngeal mask airway and advanced to the tracheobronchial tree. A systematic hilar and mediastinal lymph node survey was carried out. Sampling criteria (5mm short axis diameter) were met in station 4R and station 11Rs lymph nodes.  Sampling by transbronchial needle aspiration was performed beginning with the 4r Lymph node, followed by 11Rs using an Olympus EBUSTBNA 22 gauge needle. Further details regarding nodal size and number of samples are included in the EBUS procedural sheet which is available in AHLTA. ROSE indicated adequate lymph node sampling. All samples were sent for routine cytology. Following completion of EBUS bronchoscopy the video bronchoscope was re-inserted and after suctioning blood and secretions there was no evidence of active bleeding and the bronchoscope was subsequently removed.

Complications: No immediate complications
Estimated Blood Loss: Less than 5 cc.

Post Procedure Diagnosis:
- Technically successful flexible bronchoscopy with endobronchial ultrasound-guided biopsies.
- The patient has remained stable and has been transferred in good condition to the post-surgical monitoring unit.
- Will await final pathology results
- Plan for CT guided biopsy of RLL lesion on 6/20/17
- Will refer to ENT for evaluation of mucosal plaque seen on epiglottis.

outcomes.follow_up_plan_text: Await pathology; CT guided biopsy of RLL lesion planned; ENT referral for epiglottis plaque

Peripheral RUL lesion sampled with needle. Distinct from mediastinal EBUS.

per_code.summary: Corrected from 31653. Documentation confirms sampling of 'station 4R and station 11Rs' (2 stations).
Targeted RUL lesion with needle. distinct from EBUS targets.

global_comments: Downgraded EBUS from 31653 to 31652 based on explicit text count of 2 stations.
Granular data corrected to remove 7 and 11L which were not present in the note text.

note_text:
Indications: Diagnosis and staging of presumed lung cancer
Medications: General Anesthesia,
Consent was obtained from the patient prior to procedure after explanation in lay terms the indications, details of procedure, and potential risks and alternatives. All questions were answered and informed consent was documented as per institutional protocol. A history and physical were performed and updated in the pre-procedure assessment record. Laboratory studies and radiographs were reviewed. A time-out was performed prior to the intervention.
Following intravenous medications as per the record and topical anesthesia to the upper airway and tracheobronchial tree, the T190 video bronchoscope was introduced through the mouth, via laryngeal mask airway and advanced to the tracheobronchial tree. The laryngeal mask airway was in good position. The vocal cords were normal. The subglottic space was normal. The trachea was of normal caliber. The carina was sharp. The tracheobronchial tree was examined to at least the first subsegmental level. Bronchial mucosa and anatomy were normal; there are no endobronchial lesions. The super-dimension navigational catheter was inserted through the T190 therapeutic bronchoscope and advanced into the airway. Using navigational map we attempted to advance the 180 degree edge catheter into the proximity of the lesion within the right upper lobe. Confirmation of placement once at the point of interest with radial ultrasound showed a concentric view within the lesion. Biopsies were then performed with a variety of instruments to include peripheral needle, brush, and forceps, under fluoroscopic visualization.  After adequate samples were obtained, the video bronchoscope was then removed and the UC180F convex probe EBUS bronchoscope was introduced through the mouth, via laryngeal mask airway and advanced to the tracheobronchial tree. A systematic hilar and mediastinal lymph node survey was carried out. Sampling criteria (5mm short axis diameter) were met in station 11L, 7, 4R lymph nodes. Sampling by transbronchial needle aspiration was performed with the Olympus EBUSTBNA 22 gauge needle beginning with the 11L Lymph node, followed by the 7 lymph node and finally the 4R lymph node. A total of 5 biopsies were performed in each station. All samples were sent for routine cytology. Following completion of EBUS bronchoscopy, the Q190 video bronchoscope was then re-inserted and after suctioning blood and secretions there was no evidence of active bleeding and the bronchoscope was subsequently removed.

Complications: No immediate complications
Estimated Blood Loss: 10cc
Post Procedure Diagnosis:
- Technically successful flexible bronchoscopy with RUL and endobronchial ultrasound-guided biopsies.
- The patient has remained stable and has been transferred in good condition to the post-surgical monitoring unit.
- Will await final pathology results

clinical_context.primary_indication: Diagnosis and staging of presumed lung cancer

diagnostic_bronchoscopy.inspection_findings: Normal vocal cords, subglottic space, trachea, and carina. Normal bronchial mucosa/anatomy.

navigation_targets.notes: Lesion sampled with peripheral needle, brush, and forceps.

cpt_codes.description: Bronchoscopy with EBUS-TBNA, 3 or more stations

lines.description: Bronchoscopy with EBUS-TBNA, 3 or more stations
lines.selection_reason: Three distinct stations sampled (11L, 7, 4R) using linear EBUS. Highest valued primary procedure.

Peripheral RUL lesion sampled with needle. Distinct from mediastinal staging (EBUS). Modifier 59 required to unbundle from 31653. 31629 (Needle) selected over 31628 (Forceps) as it has higher RVU and both are bundled at same site.
SuperDimension navigation utilized to reach RUL target.

rules_applied.description: Radial EBUS (+31654) dropped because CPT prohibits reporting with Linear EBUS (31652/31653).
Diagnostic bronchoscopy (31622) bundled into therapeutic procedures.
Conventional TBNA (31629) allowed with modifier 59 because it targeted a peripheral RUL lesion, while EBUS targeted mediastinal nodes.
Multiple endoscopy reduction applies. 31653 paid at 100%. 31629 paid at ~50% of value (difference from base code).
